title: Grade 12 - Agriculture and Sustainable Food Systems 30 (2022)
subject: Practical and Applied Arts

document.title: Grade 12 - Agriculture and Sustainable Food Systems 30 (2022)

B94782C2418443E39548F9FF7F89A5C7.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

EEE7B2A18BA645D0833E12EB843F6682.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

C4EBFC64C4D04D41B9A390A766C66BB0.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

E05F1599EBDF4C24B7216F1D175AF0F2.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals

6CDC3A6086A54F8A8F7BAD8A7B0F9234.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

C892B417090A4EB0A52825350AE4D2E2.description: Relate personal work placement experience to personal and career goals.

20CFBA6C52AB4931BECA3BB4023EC6F0.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

00070FFD8E654B3DAD8B91DDA88F91E4.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

C753C37BEE454478811F3A2CD1A72A73.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

EC0B4CAFD0CD4F67B5F3762068B1EAF6.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

BBD4DBC3423B4796A9F0C5A7EA2B7B65.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

847FF521F51646F49D35E57D477840D6.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

ADE3109D442646F58BFAAE17E7E64AF3.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

FD314B09C178488D8F25C7E080B397DD.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?,Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?,  Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

B5D0CE95ABF74FB684BCDF64C85B2E66.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

20A5177F46314A0BB44FA8FB19CB17AE.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

7E022602840D47738CFD9908067BD25A.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

965F578A62254CE3867D39D41F5C04EF.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

9A1FA9E3B6FC4C0386B556F417F52127.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

1416503FF8CD4A46870A25CA02DCBB3D.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

36F66C47F9F146B7BB687B27E969A59E.description: Develop a career journey plan that supports a preferred future in the agriculture and food sector.

2FD59525A91E4D35AD9783AD0586EB2F.description: Assess personal suitability for one or more careers in the agriculture and food sector.

2638BB7D3D774A1F93E5625893E1803B.description: Research occupations of personal interest in the agriculture and food sector, considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties; skills required; the work environment, including typical hours and shifts worked and locations; current wages; physical, mental and emotional stresses; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; professional and/or licensing requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and, future trends impacting the occupation.

FB8F8C40974C4626BB7427CE72165F03.description: Conduct informational interviews with individuals employed in the agriculture and food sector to gain firsthand information about their career journeys.

3D9CF6D7F35240F281B8E17C3FF9B3D4.description: Identify the range of career opportunities available in the agriculture and food sector (e.g., farming or food production, agritourism, research, advocacy and policy) provincially, nationally and internationally.

A82CE0EBBC484E6DA3220A2C17A379F4.description: Reflect on personal values, interests, skills, personality traits, aptitude and abilities

E2936E7615B54F9E958E725D7B80EDCF.description: Assess personal suitability and interest in agriculture and food sector careers.

DD1EDFD130174AAFBBA2EDB75086F212.description: Careers in the Agriculture and Food Sector (Core)

425F1D02F5764067BDF590E609EA04E8.description: Predict how gardening can contribute to food security.

32BF9F875F984F3EA5C15595D8679F74.description: Reflect on personal and collective successes and challenges resulting from the implementation of the garden plan.

E319A103D3464518AE5BA63ACFEB288C.description: Monitor plan progress and make adjustments as required throughout the life of the garden.

2857E130A14048F6A92F3444081B1BD6.description: Implement a school or community garden plan.

7F3BD73B25454555B53414F924F1F14D.description: Identify life skills gained through gardening.

C14D97C087A64A0F9E141C4028D54698.description: Discuss the importance of, and processes (e.g., documentation, reporting) for, monitoring the operations and progress of a garden.

AA28721535484948AD15043216D39846.description: Implement a plan for a school or community garden.

71E84080D7E54B84A9C8917305DDA99D.description: Plan for establishing a school or community garden considering factors such as: permissions required; sun, water and soil needs of plants; space availability; gardening methods; weed and pest control and management; resources (e.g., funding, human, equipment, water, tools); roles and responsibilities; and, the process for distributing and sharing produce.

C44E26DAB48B4B1F9C5E043028DE3F2F.description: Research information on growing a healthy garden.

23A8098196334E2DAB008F7D83562844.description: Explore potential opportunities and challenges associated with a school garden.

019A1BBF84194A808B9A4754F9EC8DB2.description: Discuss the potential benefits (e.g., health, social, economic, cultural) and challenges (e.g., conflicts among users, competition for resources) often associated with community gardens.

FBE7712180574FF99BBA3BC3662014A4.description: Research how community gardens operate locally and elsewhere in the province.

EB661198C6014076AC3790DEDD99756E.description: Develop a plan for starting a school or community garden.

16B40ADA521A42EDAE93D223E0A7AE56.description: Evaluate current laws and regulations for animal health and welfare in Canada.

AE0BF353810E49D99DE72571C0F7A824.description: Explain the importance of animal health in supporting sustainable food systems.

0E910ECC2F7E44DBB48BBEA2DC1E7C00.description: Assess essential elements (e.g., adequate ventilation and space, proper drainage, access to food and water) of animal welfare during transportation of livestock.

40BBD6632C704F36A572E3FCA05E3552.description: Identify the role of organizations such as the National Farm Animal Care Council, Canadian Food Inspection Agency, Canadian Cattle Association and Saskatchewan Egg Producers in advocating for the health and welfare of animals raised for food in Saskatchewan and Canada.

F61938C4984348078F945224ACF840AC.description: Research elements of animal health and welfare practices, guidelines and regulations pertaining, but not limited, to: Codes of Practice; biosecurity and herd health management; use of antibiotics, hormones and vaccines; and, importing and exporting live animals.

335EF210074247D18518D80034A3062E.description: Examine the Five Freedoms (i.e., freedom from hunger and thirst; freedom from discomfort; freedom from pain, injury, and disease; freedom to express normal and natural behavior [e.g., having sufficient space]; and freedom from fear and distress) as the globally recognized gold standard in animal welfare.

C9185BE767624507ABC561B5DE0800C6.description: Discuss animal welfare as a human responsibility

1037BD6B33EF47E0BC90F0EDE76561E6.description: Assess the importance of animal health and well-being to sustainable food systems.

0CED98F84125468F8F67FCA47773BABE.description: Assess the role of digitally assisted precision agriculture in supporting sustainable food systems.

B5CD02FD45A749C292D0D0D24198D7DD.description: Research challenges and opportunities encountered by a farming operation that implements digitally assisted precision agriculture.

4308C7FAC9984469B8D4FDCAFAFFF611.description: Discuss issues (e.g., ownership, security, control) related to farming data.

68411DA266E742DA90A2E33677C3948B.description: Assess the types of data collected and how that data informs the management of small areas within fields (e.g., effective application of fertilizers, pesticides, tillage and irrigation water).

B6640FCAD3824D768AE0F639C5BF920D.description: Research technological innovations such as Global Positioning Systems [GPS], drones and precision machinery currently used in digitally assisted precision agriculture.

13E021E8454D479F97F9D3EB8F005831.description: Explain potential environmental and economic benefits of digitally assisted precision agriculture.

DAB935B33F4D479A914C09C9A08FEE4E.description: Describe the characteristics of digitally assisted precision agriculture.

BD4A30F8829D4D99B170C0A9E9AC201F.description: Investigate the importance of digital agriculture to sustainable food systems.

2334965020FD463AB7A29E21EA5B0231.description: Investigate the purpose of, and benefits derived from, Saskatchewan’s Global Institute for Food Security.

D7A9AC850C494BEAAB4E8CCFB9BE09F4.description: Describe the relationship between agriculture biotechnology and food system sustainability.

909FC42274E442288742EE72F80E6484.description: Summarize reasons for innovation in Saskatchewan’s agriculture sector.

E8C6298B829642FB9A6B4EBE64188111.description: Examine the current state and emerging opportunities associated with digital agriculture in Saskatchewan and Canada.

D75AAEBBEA754816BC1DF97C5B3E83E7.description: Investigate current application of innovative machine technology and crop and plant science biotechnology in Saskatchewan agriculture.

737F0C781F104FE4A6F0102CE75A0D39.description: Research the history of technology and innovation, including automation, in Saskatchewan agriculture.

3B5EC5AAE85341A586E512666876D8E2.description: Differentiate between natural selection, traditional plant breeding and scientific genetic manipulation in crops.

ECB6745AF065464DA632402900744ADC.description: Explain the role of research and development in agricultural innovation.

4BDAF43251954D73896FA45990CBDC15.description: Assess the impact of technology and innovation on agricultural production in Saskatchewan.

88D5BA7D46C64C7BBF44F47DB1A2D658.description: Suggest actions that individual consumers can undertake to influence the retail food sector in Canada.

8C2D4559E0DD4999A613413EE918B4AA.description: Propose strategies for making informed food choices that are not influenced by media and marketing, such as: understanding and reading food labels; noting volume quantities in comparative products at various price points; avoiding impulse buys by sticking to a pre-planned grocery list; and, questioning personal reasons for purchasing a certain food or drink.

DADC2C398C594C72954CAC1A07DB0B9C.description: Discuss the impact of food marketing, such as: creating food trends; encouraging consumer purchases of certain foods or beverages, possibly for benefits such as loyalty points, tickets to movies or sporting events or coupons for future purchases; creating links between certain foods or brands and a particular lifestyle; and, building brand loyalty.

1685D9E227B5476AAF7061938C5400B1.description: Identify personal data (e.g., age, gender, online purchasing and web browsing history) that can be harnessed for targeted marketing of food and other products

74916FD200574464A8472564CE61C887.description: Examine forms of food marketing such as branding, product packaging, event sponsorship, celebrity endorsements, contests and sales promotions, social media posts, commercials and product placement.

264783DCB973483E85032EB002E3A099.description: Assess the importance of, and ways to determine, the credibility of a source of information.

510E4CFE11F94EB09A78EF598EEB5B20.description: Identity sources (e.g., social media, newspaper, television, word of mouth) available to the Canadian public for information on the agriculture and food industry

8A934FD4DEBE48CCA288DBAA6264306A.description: Examine the influence of media and marketing on consumer food choices.

9C0CFC4621654C73A14E061BDE9ADBFC.description: Propose actions (e.g., donating unsold fresh goods to local charities, educating consumers on ways to cut household food waste, implementing employee education programs) that retailers such as grocery stores, bakeries and restaurants can take to curb food waste.

56DD0B9E293A4660AA5577E2DFC147C3.description: Investigate organizations dedicated to reducing food waste (e.g., Food Recovery Network, Second Harvest Food Rescue, Second Chance Food) in Saskatchewan and Canada

6A1EC976C4284D3991981A2DE32ECDC1.description: Develop a plan for reducing personal food waste (e.g., shopping with a grocery list, finding new ways to use leftovers, meal planning, freezing foods).

79E44044B6F642DE9EC3DA08BFB93132.description: Explain the difference between “best before” and “expiry” date labels on purchased foods.

80E4B1F6596F4666AE36F86CFBCA0535.description: Discuss the importance of curbing food loss and food waste to help address global food insecurity.

86B6FE83855B40CAB0AB2542BFFE31F0.description: Compare Canadian food waste and food loss data to that of a country in the developing world and speculate on reasons for differences.

CD1BE240C3294BC2A6B6A2825738BF03.description: Investigate the redirection of unusable and unwanted food from the human food stream into food for animals

0DEC72DA82454C7C94A8B2376D8CD495.description: Define the term upcycling as it pertains to by-products of food and reduction of food waste.

AA95FDE5C373474DB157C80B306C3AAB.description: Identify measures the Canadian agriculture industry takes to reduce or prevent food loss, including protection from loss to pests, spoilage and advances in processing and transportation.

F0F639CC9071455D9058312A46528C02.description: Research traditional Indigenous approaches to food efficiency, food waste and food loss.

78BAEAAA81A244FBBBB55170512EBD9C.description: Assess the impact (e.g., environmental, economic, social) of food loss and food waste.

AFC9110D38CB427191FEBD4FD604C8EA.description: Research factors that can contribute to food loss (e.g., pests attacking a crop, animal deaths, transportation issues) and food waste (e.g., purchasing or preparing more food than can be consumed, inadequate storage).

5D572170A34040F4BD151A3568B0E99F.description: Differentiate between food loss and food waste.

BBC71BEDE61E4156B20765DB968CBE8C.description: Assess the impacts of food loss and food waste.

92607AF7A9F240D096E32EF4DB1BD9E8.description: Investigate agricultural and food sourcing initiatives currently underway on various Saskatchewan First Nations to achieve food sovereignty.

92A2C0555CEF48648A0F3E80846653FB.description: Summarize the impact of prairie colonization and the reserve system on Indigenous food sovereignty

ED95AEAF6C334F36A2EFE55345FE2328.description: Describe the impact of government policies, including the reserve system, and the Peasant Farm Policy, and practices, including the pass system and home farm program, on historical and contemporary Indigenous agricultural practices.

6847502B97B44488BE5F6A6448DAC276.description: Investigate the historical and current impact of the Indian Act on Indigenous agricultural practices in Canada.

3F28DC52AF674938A5DDCF343E225525.description: Compare food sourcing practices of traditional Indigenous, early settler and present-day communities.

045FFA8DC6F34D6EA10E716F4CFDD219.description: Explore traditional Indigenous food sourcing practices.

C7D8BD1EE0324DB9B8CC39EFED771B50.description: Examine the impact of colonization and government policies and practices on Indigenous food sovereignty.
